questionListItems.title: Can I use my Special Account savings to pay my housing loan?

answer.body: As your Special Account savings are meant for retirement, only your Ordinary Account savings can be used for housing payments such as mortgage payments, down payments, and monthly instalments.

questionListItems.title: How much MediSave can I use to pay for approved vaccinations for myself?

answer.body:
You can use up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for patients with non-complex chronic conditions) yearly per patient from your MediSave or your approved dependants' MediSave.

Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. To use your grandchildren's or siblings' MediSave, you must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. The same yearly withdrawal limit applies for approved chronic disease treatments and health screening.

questionListItems.title: If I have used $500 from my MediSave account for my chronic condition treatment, can I still use my MediSave for my approved dependant's treatment under MediSave500/700?

answer.body:
From 1 January 2021, MediSave account holders can use their MediSave to pay for their approved dependant's treatment under MediSave500/700, up to the individual limit ($500 or $700) of the approved dependant.

As the withdrawal limits is based on a per-patient basis, withdrawals can be made for your approved dependants' even if you have withdrawn for your own treatments.

questionListItems.title: What happens if I don't have sufficient funds in my GIRO account for MediShield Life premiums?

answer.body:
If you do not have sufficient funds in your GIRO account for MediShield Life premiums, the GIRO deduction will be unsuccessful and a second GIRO deduction attempt will be made on the 15th of the next month for two months’ instalments. 

The GIRO payment plan will be suspended if there are two consecutive unsuccessful deductions. Interest and penalties may be imposed on your outstanding premiums and re-activation of the GIRO plan will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

questionListItems.title: Can I pay my MediShield Life premiums by instalment through GIRO?

answer.body:
MediShield Life premiums are generally paid using MediSave. You can use your own or your family member's MediSave Account to pay your premiums.

GIRO instalment payment is only extended, as a concession, to members with insufficient MediSave to pay their premiums.

questionListItems.title: I have an ongoing GIRO payment plan. Can I continue to pay my next MediShield Life premium by instalments?

answer.body: If you have insufficient MediSave for your next MediShield Life premium, the premium will be automatically included in your ongoing GIRO payment plan. You do not need to apply for a new GIRO payment plan. We will send you a notification on the revised GIRO payment plan when this happens.

questionListItems.title: Why do I encounter a Security Warning Message when I login to my cpf  Online Services or other online application?

answer.body:
The transaction you're performing makes use of a Secure Socket Layer (SSL) digital security certificate. This allows you to conduct safe e-transactions with 256-bit encrypted SSL connections.

Essentially, this digital certificate is an electronic document which your browser uses to authenticate our server and initiate the encryption processes. The certificate is like a stamp of approval that also carries the information needed to activate the SSL process.

questionListItems.title: How do corporate service buyers identify if the vendor is under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?

answer.body:
For self-employed persons (SEPs) who submit e-invoices, Vendors@Gov will automatically identify vendors covered under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) who log in through Corppass or Singpass. These vendors will be notified of CAYE via prompts. The e-invoice file format will be modified to store two additional columns, CAYE indicator and SEPs’ NRIC, which will subsequently be loaded into NFS@Gov and interfaced to agencies.

For invoices outside of Vendors@Gov, corporate service buyers (CSBs) need to identify and tag SEPs manually via:

  1.  the NRIC used by the SEP to transact; or
  2.  the Unique Entity Number (UEN) issued by ACRA. CSBs can use the Enterprise Data Hub (EDH) to check whether the vendor’s business entity type is a sole proprietorship or partnership. If it is a sole proprietorship, CAYE will apply.

questionListItems.title: I know that CPF LIFE Basic Plan is a legacy option. But why did Government introduce Basic Plan previously? Can I change to another plan?

answer.body:
When the CPF LIFE Basic Plan was first introduced in 2009, it was better than the previous default monthly payout scheme which did not provide payouts for life. However, to better suit Singaporeans’ evolving needs, we have since introduced Standard and Escalating plans.

The Basic Plan is retained as a legacy plan. Monthly payouts under the Basic Plan start lower than Standard Plan and will get progressively lower when your combined CPF balances eventually fall below $60,000.

If you are on the Basic Plan or other legacy plans such as the Balanced, Plus and Income plans, you can consider changing to the Escalating Plan to benefit from increasing payouts or the Standard Plan to enjoy higher and level payouts. You can make the change anytime.

It is important to note that:

  1. Once you have changed to the Standard or Escalating Plan, you cannot change back to a legacy plan.
  2. All your Retirement Account savings, including the premium refunded from your Basic Plan, will be deducted as CPF LIFE premium when the Standard or Escalating Plan is issued to you.

questionListItems.title: Can I change from a legacy plan (Basic, Balanced, Plus or Income Plan) to the Standard or Escalating Plan?

answer.body:
The Basic, Balanced, Plus and Income plans were introduced when CPF LIFE was first launched in 2009. Under these plans, extra interest earned on the first $60,000 of your CPF balances is credited to your Retirement Account (RA) and factored into your monthly payouts. As your balances are withdrawn over time to provide you with monthly payouts, the amount of monthly payouts and extra interest will decrease when your balances fall below $60,000.

If you are currently on any of the above legacy plans, you have the option to change to either the Escalating Plan or Standard Plan. Changing to the Escalating Plan will provide you with increasing payouts over time, while changing to the Standard Plan will provide you with level payouts. You can make the change anytime.

It is important to note that:

  1. Once you have changed to the Standard or Escalating Plan, you cannot change back to a legacy plan.
  2. All your RA savings, including the premium refunded from your legacy plan, will be deducted as CPF LIFE premium when the Standard or Escalating Plan is issued to you.

questionListItems.title: What should you do if you are going to nominate or have nominated Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC)?

answer.body:
If you are going to nominate SNTC as a nominee, you should contact SNTC to find out the procedures to observe. This is especially important if you have specific intentions as to how you want your CPF savings to be used or allocated by SNTC (e.g. to benefit a specific SNTC trust beneficiary).  If you have already nominated SNTC in your nomination and have yet to inform SNTC, please contact SNTC via enquiries@sntc.org.sg or office hotline 62789598 to inform them of your nomination.

Please ensure that SNTC is kept informed of your intentions as CPF Board is not in a position to enforce or ensure that the organisation will apply the CPF savings received in the manner you intended.

questionListItems.title: What should you do if you want to nominate Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS), Mosques, or Madrasahs as your CPF nominee?

answer.body:
All CPF nominations must be to a legal entity. All mosques and madrasahs in Singapore are vested entities of Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (Muis).

If you intend to nominate any mosque or madrasah, or Muis, appoint Muis as a nominee by indicating the Unique Entity Number (UEN) T08GB0028L in the ‘Registration number of organisation’ field.

Once done, inform Muis via this form https://go.gov.sg/muis-cpfnomination. This will ensure that your CPF savings are directed to your intended entity.

For more information, please contact Muis at https://www.muis.gov.sg/Contact-Info.

questionListItems.title: Do I need to notify CPF Board if I get married after making my CPF nomination?

answer.body:
If your marriage is registered with the Singapore Registry of Marriages (ROM) or Registry of Muslim Marriages (ROMM)

You do not need to notify us of your marriage. However, any CPF nomination you had made previously will be revoked upon your marriage. You are strongly encouraged to make a new CPF nomination so that your CPF savings will be distributed according to your wishes.

If your marriage is not registered with ROM or ROMM

You will be required to complete the Notification of Marriage in relation to CPF Nomination form so that we are informed of your marriage. If you have a CPF nomination made before this marriage, your nomination will be revoked.

Alternatively, you can make a new nomination after getting married if you do not wish to notify us of your marriage. This new nomination will supersede any previous nomination you had made before your marriage.

questionListItems.title: Will I be able to access the CPF account information of a deceased CPF member?

answer.body:
If CPF Board is notified of the death before 1 February 2024

If the deceased member had appointed authorised persons in his/her CPF nomination, only the authorised persons can access his/her CPF account information.

If CPF Board is notified of the death on or after 1 February 2024 

Nominees and family members who are eligible beneficiaries under intestacy laws will be able to access a deceased member's CPF account information.

questionListItems.title: What happens if the CPF Board deems that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity?

answer.body: If the CPF Board deems that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity within the meaning of section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act 2008, the Board will invalidate the nomination. The previous CPF nomination (if any) made by the member would remain valid (assuming the member did not lack capacity when he made the previous CPF nomination). The member's CPF savings would be distributed in accordance with the intention of the member in his previous valid CPF nomination. If there is no previous valid CPF nomination, the CPF savings would be paid to the Public Trustee for distribution in accordance with intestacy laws.
